welcomeSubtitle: Discover the plants around you easily. Just take a picture, and we'll provide the details.
model1Description: Recommended for general plant identification. Covers a wide variety of plants, making it suitable for diverse environments.
model2Description: Best for specific plant identification. Focuses on a smaller set of plants for higher accuracy.
aiDisclaimer: Note: AI may sometimes make mistakes. Always double-check the results!
uploadError: An error occurred while uploading the image
MilkThistleDesc: A plant known for its detoxifying properties, often used to support liver health.
MilkThistleToxicity: Generally safe for most people; can cause allergic reactions or gastrointestinal issues in some cases.
MilkThistleBenefits: Supports liver health, detoxifies the body.
MilkThistleCooking: Can be used in herbal teas or as an extract.
CheeseweedDesc: A plant sometimes used in traditional medicine for its soothing properties.
CheeseweedToxicity: Non-toxic in small amounts, but large consumption can cause digestive discomfort.
CheeseweedCooking: Can be added to salads or used in soups.
EcballiumDesc: Also known as the squirting cucumber, it is a wild plant known for its explosive fruit dispersal.
EcballiumToxicity: Toxic; ingestion or contact with its juice can cause severe gastrointestinal irritation and skin or eye irritation.
EcballiumBenefits: Has limited traditional medicinal uses but should be handled with care.
EcballiumCooking: Not used in cooking due to its toxicity.
NettlesDesc: A plant known for its stinging hairs, often used in teas and herbal remedies after processing.
NettlesToxicity: Fresh nettles can cause skin irritation, but they are safe to consume after cooking or drying.
NettlesBenefits: Rich in vitamins and minerals, supports kidney health and reduces inflammation.
NettlesCooking: Used in soups, teas, and as a cooked vegetable.
ParsleyDesc: A versatile herb used in cooking and garnishing, rich in nutrients and antioxidants.
ParsleyToxicity: Safe for most people, but excessive consumption may cause mild stomach upset.
ParsleyBenefits: Rich in vitamin C and K, supports bone health and immune function.
ParsleyCooking: Commonly used in salads, soups, and as a garnish.
CorianderDesc: An aromatic herb used in cooking, both the leaves and seeds are widely used.
CorianderToxicity: Safe for most people; rarely causes allergic reactions.
CorianderBenefits: Supports digestion, lowers blood sugar levels, and has antibacterial properties.
CorianderCooking: Used in curries, soups, and as a garnish.
OleanderDesc: A highly toxic ornamental plant with beautiful flowers.
OleanderToxicity: Highly toxic; ingestion or contact with sap can cause severe poisoning or death.
OleanderBenefits: Primarily ornamental, with no known health benefits due to its toxicity.

steps.description: Grind the milk thistle seeds to obtain a fine powder.
Boil 1 cup of water and add the seed powder.
Let the tea simmer for 5 minutes and then strain it.
Serve the tea hot, adding honey if desired for sweetness.
Wash the cheeseweed leaves. No need to boil as they are tender.
Mix the stuffing ingredients and start stuffing and rolling like grape leaves.
Layer tomato slices at the bottom of the pot and arrange stuffed leaves on top.
Add water mixed with tomato paste, salt, and chicken broth powder, then cook.
Let it cook until done. Serve and enjoy.

cookingRecipesData.name: Not edible
ingredients: Ecballium contains toxic cucurbitacins and all parts of the plant are potentially lethal if ingested.

steps.description: This plant is toxic and unsuitable for cooking.
Wear gloves, clean the nettles, and chop them.
Peel and cube the potatoes.
Boil the potatoes until partially cooked.
Drain the potatoes and add them with nettles and broth to a pot.
Bring the mixture to a boil.
Blend the soup using a hand blender.
Add cream and seasonings to taste, then stir.

cookingRecipesData.name: Parsley Tea
ingredients: ¼ cup of fresh parsley leaves per cup of boiled water

steps.description: Remove fresh parsley leaves from the stems.
Add ¼ cup of parsley leaves for each cup of boiled water.
Boil for 5 to 10 minutes.
Strain the leaves and pour the mixture into a cup for serving.

cookingRecipesData.name: Stuffed Potatoes with Coriander
ingredients: ½ kg of coarsely minced meat
Pinch of salt and black pepper
½ bunch of chopped fresh coriander

steps.description: Peel the potatoes, hollow them out, and keep the cores for the filling.
Fry the potatoes until golden brown.
Mix the minced meat with mashed garlic, coriander, onions, and spices.
Stuff the potatoes with the mixture and bake them in the oven until cooked.
Serve the stuffed potatoes hot.
